question: Question 1 If any two columns of a determinant P= [latex]\begin{vmatrix} 4 & 7 & 8\\ 3 & 1 & 5\\ 9& 6 & 2 \end{vmatrix}[/latex]  are interchanged, which one of the following statements regarding the value of the determinant is CORRECT?
solution: Property of determinant: If any two row or column are interchanged, then mangnitude of determinant remains same but sign changes.

options.A: Absolute value remains unchanged but sign will change.
options.B: Both absolute value and sign will change.
options.C: Absolute value will change but sign will not change
options.D: Both absolute value and sign will remain unchanged

question: Question 2 Among the four normal distributions with probability density functions as shown below, which one has the lowest variance?
solution: We know that probability density function of normal distribution is given by [latex]F(x)=\frac{1}{\sigma \sqrt{2 \pi}}e^{-\frac{1}{2}\left ( \frac{x-\mu }{\sigma } \right )^2}[/latex] For having lowest variance [latex](\sigma ^2)[/latex], standard deviation [latex](\sigma )[/latex] will be lowest. From the density function [latex]f(x)[/latex], we can say that as Ïƒ decreases  [latex]F(x)[/latex] will increase, so curve having highest peak has lowest standard deviation and variance.

question: Question 3 Simpson's [latex]1/3[/latex]  rule is used to integrate the function [latex]\frac{3}{5}x^{2}+\frac{9}{5}[/latex] between x = 0 and x = 1 using the least number of equal sub -intervals. The value of the integral is _____________
solution: [latex]f(x)=\frac{3}{5} x^{2}+\frac{9}{5}[/latex] [latex] \begin{array}{|c|c|c|c|}\hline x & 0 & 0.5 & 1 \\\hline f(x) & 1.8 & 1.95 & 2.4 \\\hline\end{array}\\ \Rightarrow\int_{0}^{1} f(x)=\frac{h}{3}\left[y_{0}+4 y_{1}+y_{2}\right][/latex] [latex] =\frac{0.5}{3}[1.8+4(1.95)+2.4]=2[/latex]

question: Question 4 The value of [latex]\lim_{x\rightarrow 0}\frac{1-cos(x^{2})}{2x^{4}}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{1-\cos \left(x^{2}\right)}{2 x^{4}} \quad [/latex] putting the x [latex]\rightarrow 0 [/latex] we get [latex] \frac{0}{0} [/latex] form Applying L' Hospital rule [latex] \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{2 x \sin \left(x^{2}\right)}{8 x^{3}} \quad [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin \left(x^{2}\right)}{4 x^{2}} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{1}{4} \lim _{x \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin \left(x^{2}\right)}{x^{2}}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \frac{1}{4} \lim _{x^{2} \rightarrow 0} \frac{\sin \left(x^{2}\right)}{x^{2}}=\frac{1}{4} \times 1=\frac{1}{4}[/latex]

question: Question 5 Given two complex numbers [latex]z_{1}=5+(5\sqrt{3})i[/latex]  and [latex]z_{2}=2/\sqrt{3}+2i[/latex], the argument of [latex]z_{1}/z_{2}[/latex]  in degrees is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} z_{1} &=5+(5 \sqrt{3}) i \\ z_{2} &=\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}+2 i \\ \arg \left(z_{1}\right) &=\theta_{1}=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{5 \sqrt{3}}{5}\right) \\ \theta_{1} &=60^{\circ} \\ \arg \left(z_{2}\right) &=\theta_{2}=\tan ^{-1}\left(\frac{2}{\frac{2}{\sqrt{3}}}\right) \\ \theta_{2} &=60^{\circ} \\ \arg \left(\frac{z_{1}}{z_{2}}\right) &=\arg \left(z_{1}\right)-\arg \left(z_{2}\right) \\ &=60-60=0^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 6 Consider fully developed flow in a circular pipe with negligible entrance length effects. Assuming the mass flow rate, density and friction factor to be constant, if the length of the pipe  is doubled and the diameter is halved, the head loss due to friction will increase by a factor of
solution: Head loss due to friction, [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{f}&=\frac{f L V^{2}}{2 g d}\\ &\text{Mass flow rate,}\\ m&=\rho A V=\rho \times \frac{\pi}{4} d^{2} V\\ or\quad V&=\frac{4 m}{\rho \pi d^{2}} \\ \therefore \quad h_{f}&=\frac{f L}{2 g d} \times \frac{16 m^{2}}{\rho^{2} \pi^{2} d^{4}}\\ &=\frac{8 f m^{2}}{\rho^{2} \pi^{2}} \times \frac{L}{d^{5}} \\ &=C \times \frac{L}{d^{5}} \text { where } C=\frac{8 f m^{2}}{\rho^{2} \pi^{2}} \\ h_{f_{1}}&=C \times \frac{L}{d^{5}}\\ and\quad h_{2} &=C \times \frac{2 L}{(d / 2)^{5}}=\frac{C \times 2 L}{\frac{d^{5}}{2^{5}}} \\ &=\frac{C \times 2 \times 2^{5} L}{d^{5}}=\frac{C \times 64 L}{d^{5}} \\ h_{1 / 2} &=64 h_{11} \end{aligned}[/latex] The head loss due to friction will increase by a factor of 64

question: Question 7 The Blasius equation related to boundary layer theory is a
solution: [latex]2 \frac{d^{3} f}{d \eta^{3}}+f \frac{d^{2} f}{d \eta^{2}}=0 [/latex] third-order non-linear differential equation.

question: Question 8 For flow of viscous fluid over a flat plate, if the fluid temperature is the same as the plate temperature, the thermal boundary layer is
solution: For the flow of viscous fluid over a flat plate if the fluid temperature is the same as the plate temperature the thermal boundary layer is not formed at all because boundary layer formation took place if there is some difference in fluid property of no slip layer and remaining fluid. As here given that fluid is viscous and flowing over a flat plate. Here, definitely a kinematic boundary layer will be formed but as there is no temperature difference so no formation of thermal boundary layer.

options.A: thinner than the velocity boundary layer
options.B: thicker than the velocity boundary layer
options.C: of the same thickness as the velocity boundary layer

question: Question 9 For an ideal gas with constant values of specific heats, for calculation of the specific enthalpy,
solution: For constant valves of specific heats dh = F(T) only So for calculation of specific enthalpy it is sufficient to know only the temperature.

options.A: it is sufficient to know only the temperature
options.B: both temperature and pressure are required to be known
options.C: both temperature and volume are required to be known
options.D: both temperature and mass are required to be known

question: Question 10 A Carnot engine (CE-1) works between two temperature reservoirs A and B, where [latex]T_{A}[/latex] = 900 K and [latex]T_{B}[/latex]  = 500 K. A second Carnot engine (CE-2) works between temperature reservoirs B and C, where [latex]T_{C}[/latex]  = 300 K. In each cycle of CE-1 and CE-2, all the heat rejected by CE-1 to reservoir B is used by CE-2. For one cycle of operation, if the net Q absorbed by CE-1 from reservoir A is 150 MJ, the net heat rejected to reservoir C by CE-2 (in MJ) is ______________
solution: For Carnot engine (CE-2) [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{2}&=1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}}\\ \text{also}\qquad \eta_{2} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \therefore \quad 1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}}\\ \text{or}\qquad\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \frac{300}{500} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{\frac{5 \times 150}{9}}\\ \text{or}\qquad Q_{c}&=50 \mathrm{MJ} \end{aligned}[/latex] For Carnot engine (CE-2) [latex] \begin{aligned} \eta_{2}&=1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}}\\ \text{also}\qquad \eta_{2} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \therefore \quad 1-\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=1-\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}}\\ \text{or}\qquad\frac{T_{C}}{T_{B}} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{Q_{B}} \\ \frac{300}{500} &=\frac{Q_{C}}{\frac{5 \times 150}{9}}\\ \text{or}\qquad Q_{c}&=50 \mathrm{MJ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 11 Air enters a diesel engine with a density of 1.0 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] . The compression ratio is 21. At steady state, the air intake is 30 x [latex]10^{-3}[/latex]  kg/s and the net work output is 15 kW. The mean effective pressure (in kPa) is ____________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \rho &= 1kg/m^3\\ r&= \frac{V_1}{V_c}=21\\ m &=30 \times 10^{-3}kg/s \\ W&=15kW \\ V_1&=\frac{m}{\rho }=\frac{30 \times 10^{-3}}{1}m^3/s \\ &= 30 \times 10^{-3}m^3/s\\ V_c &=\frac{V_1}{r}=\frac{30 \times 10^{-3}}{21} \\ &= 1.428 \times 10^{-3}m^3/s\\ V_s&=V_1-V_c \\ &= 30 \times 10^{-3} -1.428 \times 10^{-3}\\ &= 28.572 \times 10^{-3}m^3/s \end{aligned}[/latex] Mean effective pressure, [latex]\rho _m=\frac{W}{V_s}=\frac{15}{28.572 \times 10^{-3}} [/latex] [latex]\;\;\;=524.99kW\approx 525kW[/latex]

question: Question 12 A stream of moist air (mass flow rate = 10.1 kg/s) with humidity ratio of 0.01 [latex]\frac{kg}{kg \; dry \; air}[/latex]  mixes with a second stream of superheated water vapour flowing at 0.1 kg/s. Assuming proper and uniform mixing with no condensation, the humidity ratio of the final stream  (in [latex]\frac{kg}{kg \; dry \; air}[/latex] )  is  _____________
solution: Mass flow rate of moist air [latex]=10.1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] [latex] \text { Humidity ratio: } \omega=\frac{m_{v}}{m_{a}}=0.01 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s}[/latex] Mass of moist air = Mass of dry air + Mass of water vapour [latex] \begin{aligned} 10.1 &=m_{a}+0.01 \times m_{a} \\ 10.1 m_{a} &=10.1 \end{aligned}[/latex] Mass of dry air: [latex]m_{a}=\frac{10.1}{1.01}=10 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} [/latex] Mass of water vapour, [latex] \begin{aligned} m_{v_{1}} &=10.1-10=0.1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ m_{v_{2}} &=0.1 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \\ \left(m_{\mathrm{v}}\right)_{\mathrm{total}} &=m_{v_{1}}+m_{v_{2}}=0.2 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] Humidity ratio [latex] \begin{aligned} \omega_{\mathrm{final}}=\frac{m_{v}}{m_{\mathrm{a}}} &=\frac{0.2}{10}\\ &=0.02 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{kg} \text{ of dry air} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 13 A wheel of radius r rolls without slipping on a horizontal surface shown below. If the velocity of point P is 10 m/s in the horizontal direction, the magnitude of velocity of point Q (in m/s) is ______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{P} &=r \omega=10 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ V_{Q} &=2 r \omega=2 \times 10 \\ &=20 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 14 Consider a slider crank mechanism with nonzero masses and inertia. A constant torque [latex]\tau[/latex]  is applied on the crank as shown in the figure. Which of the following plots best resembles variation of crank angle, [latex]\theta[/latex]  versus time
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \tau(\text { torque }) &=I \ddot{\theta} \\ \tau &=\text { constant } \\ I &=\text { constant } \\ \tau &=I \frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}} \\ \frac{d^{2} \theta}{d t^{2}} &=\frac{\tau}{I} \\ \frac{d \theta}{d t} &=\frac{\tau}{I} t+C_{1} \\ \theta &=\frac{\tau}{I} \frac{t^{2}}{2}+C_{1} t+C_{2}\\ \theta=f(t)&= \text{ parabolic function}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] But practically graph will be fluctuating about ideal  parabolic curve.

question: Question 15 Consider a stepped shaft subjected to a twisting moment applied at B as shown in the figure. Assume shear modulus, G = 77 GPa. The angle of twist at C (in degrees) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \theta_{C}=\theta_{B} &=\frac{T L}{G J} \\ &=\frac{10 \times 10^{3} \times 500 \times 32}{\pi \times(20)^{4} \times 77 \times 10^{3}} \\ &=4.1338946 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{radian}=0.2368^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 16 Two identical trusses support a load of 100 N as shown in the figure. The length of each truss is  1.0 m; cross-sectional area is 200 [latex]mm^{2}[/latex] ; Young's modulus E = 200 GPa. The force in the truss AB (in N) is _________
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{F_{A B}}{\sin 120^{\circ}} &=\frac{100}{\sin 120^{\circ}} \\ \text{or}\qquad F_{A B} &=100 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 17 Consider a steel (Young's modulus E = 200 GPa) column hinged on both sides. Its height is 1.0 m and cross-section is 10 mm x 20 mm. The lowest Euler critical buckling load (in N) is __________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F &=\frac{\pi^{2} E I}{L_{e}^{2}}=\frac{\pi^{2} \times 200 \times 10^{3} \times 20 \times 10^{3}}{12 \times(1000)^{3}} \\ &=3289.868 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 18 A swimmer can swim 10 km in 2 hours when swimming along the flow of a river. While swimming against the flow, she takes 5 hours for the same distance. Her speed in still water (in km/h) is _____
solution: Let velocity of woman in still water =x Velocity of river flow =y (i) Swimming along the river flow Resultant velocity of woman =x+y [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 2=\frac{10}{x+y} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad x+y=5 \qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] (ii) Swimming againts the river flow Resultant velocity of woman =x-y [latex] \Rightarrow \quad 5=\frac{10}{x-y} [/latex] [latex] x-y=2 \qquad \ldots(ii)[/latex] Adding (i) and (ii) [latex] 2 x =7 [/latex] [latex] x =3.5 \mathrm{km} / \mathrm{h}[/latex]

question: Question 19 Which one of the following is the most conservative fatigue failure criterion?
solution: When a component is subjected to fluctuating stresses there is mean stress [latex](\sigma _m)[/latex] as well as stress amplitude [latex](\sigma _a)[/latex]. It has been observed that the mean stress component has an effect on fatigue failure when it is present in combination with an alternating component. When the component is subjected to both component of stress [latex](\sigma _m)[/latex] and [latex](\sigma _a)[/latex] the actual failure occurs at different scattered points as shown in figure. There exist a border which decides sole region from unsole region for various combinations of [latex](\sigma _m)[/latex] and [latex](\sigma _a)[/latex] and different criterion are proposed to constant the borderline dividing safe zone and failure zone, they include Gerber line, soderberg line, Goodman line, ASME elliptic. Gerber Line: A parabolic curve jointing [latex]\sigma _e[/latex] on the ordinate to [latex]\sigma _{ut}[/latex] on the abscissa is called Gerber line. It is written as [latex]\left (\frac{\sigma _a}{\sigma _e} \right )+\left (\frac{\sigma _m}{\sigma _{ut}} \right )^2=1[/latex] Soderberg Line: A straight line joining [latex]\sigma _e[/latex] on the ordinate to [latex]\sigma _{yt}[/latex] on the abscissa is called soderberg line. It is written as [latex]\left (\frac{\sigma _a}{\sigma _e} \right )+\left (\frac{\sigma _m}{\sigma _{yt}} \right )=1[/latex] Goodman Line: A straight line joining [latex]\sigma _e[/latex] on the ordinate to [latex]\sigma _{ut}[/latex] on the abscissa is called the Goodman line. It is written as [latex]\left (\frac{\sigma _a}{\sigma _e} \right )+\left (\frac{\sigma _m}{\sigma _{ut}} \right )=1[/latex] ASME Elliptic: The ASME elliptic is written as [latex]\left (\frac{\sigma _a}{\sigma _e} \right )^2+\left (\frac{\sigma _m}{\sigma _{yt}} \right )^2=1[/latex] The soderberg line is a more conservative failure criterion and there is no need to consider even yielding in this case.

question: Question 20 Which one of the following types of stress-strain relationship best describes the behaviour of brittle materials, such as ceramics and thermosetting plastics, ([latex]\sigma[/latex] = stress and [latex]\varepsilon[/latex] = strain)?
solution: We know that brittle material does not show elongation when external load is applied on them and alter certain amount of load they get cracked from unexpected point. The amount of ultimate load and point of fracture can not be predetermined and elongation is also very-very less so these properties are best described by option (D).

question: Question 21 Match the following products with preferred manufacturing processes:

Question 22 Holes of diameter [latex]25.0_{+0.020}^{+0.040}[/latex]  mm are assembled interchangeably with the pins of diameter [latex]25.0_{-0.008}^{+0.005}[/latex]  mm. the minimum arance in the assembly will becle
solution: Minimum clearances [latex]=(\text { Hole })_{\text {minimum }}- (\text { Shaft })_{\text {maximum }} [/latex] [latex] 25.02-25.005=0.015mm[/latex]

question: Question 23 Under certain cutting conditions, doubling the cutting speed reduces the tool life to [latex](1/16)^{th}[/latex] of the original. Taylor's tool life index(n) for this tool-workpiece combination will be ___________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_{1} T_{1}^{n} &=V_{2} T_{2}^{n} \\ \Rightarrow \quad V_{1}\left(T_{1}\right)^{n} &=2 V_{1}\left[\frac{1}{16} T_{1}\right]^{n} \\ n &=0.25 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 In a linear arc welding process, the heat input per unit length is inversely proportional to
solution: In Linear arc welding process the heat input per unit length depends on many factors. (A) Welding current: As welding current increase as heat input increases because we know that heat input is [latex]I^2RT[/latex] so [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto ( \text{current} )^2[/latex] (B) Welding Voltage: As welding voltage increase as heat input also increase because we know that heat input is [latex]\frac{V^2}{R}[/latex] [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto ( \text{voltage} )^2[/latex] (C) Welding Speed: As welding speed increase as welding electrode spend less time to release heat so as speed increase as heat input per unit length decrease proportionaly [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto \frac{1}{( \text{welding speed} )}[/latex] (D) Duty cycle: Duty cycle is defined as the % of time for which arc is on without overheating element of welding machine so [latex](\text{Heat input per unit length})\propto ( \text{duty cycle} )[/latex]

options.D: duty cycle of the power source

question: Question 25 The function of  interpolator in a CNC machine controller is to
solution: Interpolator in a CNC machine controller is used for circular interpolation purpose. It simple means that interpolator gives motion (or feed) to the coordinate axes for circular interpolations.

options.D: perform Miscellaneous (M) functions (tool change, coolant control etc.)

question: Question 26 Consider a spatial curve in three-dimensional space given in parametric form by [latex]x(t)=cos t[/latex], [latex]y(t)=sin t[/latex], [latex]z(t)=(2/\pi)t, 0\leq t\leq \pi/2[/latex]. The length of the curve is _______
solution: [latex]S=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{\left(\frac{d x}{d t}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{d y}{d t}\right)^{2}+\left(\frac{d z}{d t}\right)^{2}} d t [/latex] [latex] S=\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{(-\sin t)^{2}+(\cos t)^{2}+\left(\frac{2}{\pi}\right)^{2}} d t [/latex] [latex] =\int_{0}^{\pi / 2} \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{4}{\pi^{2}}\right)} d t=\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{4}{\pi^{2}}\right)}[t]_{0}^{\pi / 2} [/latex] [latex] =\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{4}{\pi^{2}}\right)}\left(\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=1.86[/latex]

question: Question 27 Consider an ant crawling along the curve [latex](x-2)^{2}+y^{2}=4[/latex] , where x and y are in meters. The ant starts at the point (4, 0) and moves counter-clockwise with a speed of 1.57 meters per second. The time taken by the ant to reach the point (2, 2) is  (in seconds) ____________
solution: [latex](x-2)^{2}+\left(y^{2}\right)=(2)^{2},[/latex] is a circle of radius 2m and centre at (2,0) Time to reach from (4,0) to (2,2) is [latex] \text{Time } =\frac{\text { Distance }}{\text { Speed }} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{\left(\frac{2 \pi r}{4}\right)}{1.57}=\frac{\left(\frac{2 \pi^{2}}{4}\right)}{1.57}=\frac{\pi}{1.57}=2 \mathrm{s}[/latex]

question: Question 28 Find the solution of [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d}^{2}y}{\mathrm{d} x^{2}}=y[/latex]  which passes through the origin and the point ([latex]\ln 2,3/4[/latex]).
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{d^{2} y}{d x^{2}} &=y \\ \Rightarrow D^{2} y &=y \\ \left(D^{2}-1\right) y &=0 \\ D^{2}-1 &=0 \\ D &=\pm 1 \\ y &=C_{1} e^{x}+C_{2} e^{-x} \qquad ...(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] Given point passes through origin [latex] \Rightarrow O=C_{1}+C_{2} [/latex] [latex] C_{1}=-C_{2} [/latex] Also, point passes through (In 2,3 / 4 ) [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \frac{3}{4}=C_{1} e^{\ln 2}+C_{2} e^{\ln 2} [/latex] [latex] \frac{3}{4} =2 C_{1}+\frac{C_{2}}{2} [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow \quad C_{2}+4 C_{1} =1.5 \qquad ...(ii)[/latex] From (i) [latex]]C_{1}=-C_{2}[/latex],  putting in (ii), we get [latex] \Rightarrow \quad-3 C_{2}=1.5 [/latex] [latex] C_{2}=-0.5 [/latex] [latex] \therefore \quad C_{1}=0.5 [/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow y=0.5\left(e^{x}-e^{-x}\right) [/latex] [latex] y=\frac{e^{x}-e^{-x}}{2}[/latex]

question: Question 29 The probability of obtaining at least two "SIX" in throwing a fair dice 4 times is
solution: Let P be the probability that six occurs on a fair  dice, [latex] \therefore P=\frac{1}{6}[/latex] [latex] \therefore q=\frac{5}{6}[/latex] Let X , be the number of times 'six' occurs, Probability of obtaining at least two 'six' in throwing a fair dice 4 times is =1-\{P(X=0)+P(X=1)\} [/latex] [latex] =1-\left\{^{4} C_{0} p^{0} q^{4}+^{4} C_{1} p^{1} q^{3}\right\} [/latex] [latex] =1-\left\{\left(\frac{5}{6}\right)^{4}+\left[4 \times \frac{1}{6} \times\left(\frac{5}{6}\right)^{3}\right]\right\} [/latex] [latex] =1-\left\{\frac{125}{144}\right\}=\frac{19}{144} [/latex]

question: Question 30 In the assembly shown below, the part dimensions are: [latex] L1 = 22.0^{\pm 0.01}[/latex]mm, [latex]L2 = L3 =10.0^{\pm 0.005}[/latex]mm.  Assuming the normal distribution of part dimensions, the dimension  in [latex]L_{4}[/latex]  mm for assembly condition would be:
solution: For dimensions of [latex]L_4[/latex], we deduce Maximum dimension of [latex]L_4[/latex] =(maximum of [latex]L_1[/latex])-(minimum of [latex]L_2[/latex] and [latex]L_3[/latex]) =(22.0+0.01)-2(10.0-0.005)=2.02 Minimum dimension of [latex]L_4[/latex] =(minimum of [latex]L_4[/latex])-(maximum of [latex]L_2[/latex] and [latex]L_3[/latex]) =(22.0-0.01)-2(10.0-0.005)=1.98 Total tolerance = 2.02-1.98=0.04 For bilateral dimension system, it can be expressed as[latex]\pm 0.02[/latex]. So, the dimension of [latex]L_4[/latex] can be expressed in bilateral system as [latex]2.0 \pm 0.02[/latex] mm.

question: Question 31 A DC welding power source has a linear voltage-current (V-I) characteristic with open circuit voltage of 80 V and a short circuit current of 300 A. For maximum arc power, the current (in Amperes) should be set as_________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V&=V_{O C}-\left(\frac{V_{O C}}{I_{S C}}\right) I \\ \Rightarrow\quad V&=80-\left(\frac{80}{300}\right) I \\ P&=V I \\ &=(80-0.2666 I) I \\ &=80 I-0.2666 I^{2} \end{aligned}[/latex] for power to be maximum [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad\left(\frac{d P}{d I}\right)=0 \\ \Rightarrow 80-2 \times 0.2666 I=0 \\ \Rightarrow\quad \quad I=150 \mathrm{A} \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 32 A triangular facet in a CAD model has vertices: P1(0,0,0); P2(1,1,0) and P3(1,1,1). The area of the facet is
solution: [latex]\text{Area}=\frac{1}{2} \times \sqrt{2} \times 1=\frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}=0.707[/latex]

question: Question 33 Following data refers to the activities of a project, where, node 1 refers to the start and node 5 refers to the end of the project. The critical path (CP) in the network is
solution: Critical path = 1-4-3-5

question: Question 34 For a canteen, the actual demand for disposable cups was 500 units in January and 600 units in February. The forecast for the month of January was 400 units. The forecast for the month of March considering smoothing coefficient as 0.75 is ________
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} F_{\mathrm{Feb}} &=F_{\mathrm{Jan}}+\alpha\left[D_{\mathrm{Jan}}-F_{\mathrm{Jan}}\right] \\ &=400+0.75[500-400] \\ &=475 \\ F_{\mathrm{March}} &=F_{\mathrm{Feb}}+\alpha\left[D_{\mathrm{Feb}}-F_{\mathrm{Feb}}\right] \\ &=475+0.75[600-475] \\ &=568.75 \approx 569 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 35 An orthogonal turning operation is carried out under the following conditions: rake angle = [latex]5^{\circ}[/latex] ; spindle rotational speed = 400 rpm; axial feed = 0.4 m/min and radial depth of cut = 5 mm. The chip thickness, [latex]t_{c}[/latex], is found to be 3 mm. The shear angle (in degrees) in this turning process is_____
solution: Rake angle [latex](\alpha)=5^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} N &=400 \mathrm{rpm} \\ \text { Axial feed } &=0.4 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{min} \\ &=\frac{0.4 \times 1000}{400}=1 \mathrm{mm} / \mathrm{rev} \end{aligned}[/latex] Radial dreeth of cut [latex]=5 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] Chip thickness: [latex]r_{c}= 3 \mathrm{mm} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} r&=\text{chip thickness ratio}\\ &= \frac{t}{t_{c}}=\left(\frac{1}{3}\right) \\ \Rightarrow \tan\phi&=\frac{r\cos\alpha}{1-r\sin\alpha}\\ &=\frac{\frac{1}{3} \cos \left(5^{\circ}\right)}{1-\frac{1}{3} \sin \left(5^{\circ}\right)} \\ \tan \phi &=0.342\\ \text{or }\qquad \phi&=\tan ^{-1}(0.342)=18.88^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 36 The solidification time of a casting is proportional to [latex](V/A)^{2}[/latex] , where V is the volume of the casting and A is the total casting surface area losing heat. Two cubes of same material and size are cast using sand casting process. The top face of one of the cubes is completely insulated. The ratio of the solidification time for the cube with top face insulated to that of the other cube is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} T_{\text {solidification }}&= k\left(\frac{V}{A}\right)^{2} \\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}} &=\frac{k\left(\frac{V_{1}}{A_{1}}\right)^{2}}{k\left(\frac{V_{2}}{A_{2}}\right)^{2}} \\ V_{1} &=V_{2}\\ \Rightarrow \quad \frac{T_{1}}{T_{2}}&=\frac{A_{2}^{2}}{A_{1}^{2}}=\frac{\left(6 a^{2}\right)^{2}}{\left(5 a^{2}\right)^{2}}=\frac{36}{25} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 37 In a slab rolling operation, the maximum thickness reduction ([latex]\Delta h_{max}[/latex] ) is given by [latex]\Delta h_{max}[/latex]=[latex]\mu ^{2}R[/latex] , where R is the radius of the roll and ? is the coefficient of friction between the roll and the sheet. If [latex]\mu [/latex] = 0.1, the maximum angle subtended by the deformation zone at the centre of the roll (bite angle in degrees) is _______
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Delta h_{\max } &=\mu^{2} R \\ \Delta h &=D(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \Rightarrow \quad \mu^{2} R&=D(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \Rightarrow \quad(0.1)^{2}&=2(1-\cos \alpha) \\ \text{or }\quad \alpha&=5.73^{\circ} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 38 Considering massless rigid rod and small oscillations, the natural frequency (in rad/s) of vibration of the system shown in the figure is
solution: [latex]Q \rightarrow [/latex] Change in angular positions of rod in anticlockwise direction. Restoring torque [latex]=(K r \theta)r[/latex] will act in clockwise direction [latex] \begin{aligned} \tau &=-K r^{2} \theta \\ l \alpha &=-K r^{2} \theta \\ \alpha &=-\frac{K r^{2}}{I} \theta \\ \omega_{n} &=\sqrt{\frac{K r^{2}}{I}} \\ I &=m\left(2 r^{2}\right)=1\left(4 r^{2}\right) \\ I &=\sqrt{\frac{400 \times r^{2}}{1 \times 4 r^{2}}}=\sqrt{\frac{400}{4}} \\ \omega_{n} &=10 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 39 For the truss shown in figure, the magnitude of the force in member PR and the support reaction at R are respectively
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{O} &=0 \\ R_{v} \times 4-50 \times 4 &=0 \\ R_{v} &=50 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex] Force in member [latex] Q R=50 \mathrm{kN}[/latex] (Tensile) Free body diagram of joint R [latex] \begin{aligned} F_{P B} \cos 45^{\circ} &=50 \\ F_{P R} &=\frac{50}{\cos 45^{\circ}} \\ F_{P A} &=70.71 \mathrm{kN} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 40 A ball of mass 0.1 kg, initially at rest, is dropped from height of 1 m. Ball hits the ground and bounces off the ground. Upon impact with the ground, the velocity reduces by 20%. The height  (in m) to which the ball will rise is _______
solution: Velocity with which ball hits the ground [latex] \begin{aligned} V_{1} &=\sqrt{2 g h}=\sqrt{2 \times 9.81 \times 1} \\ &=4.4294 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \\ \text{and }\qquad V_{2} &=0.8 \times 4.4294=3.54 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \Rightarrow[/latex] Now [latex] \frac{1}{2} m V_{2}^{2}[/latex] is kinetic energy of ball which will be decreasing as it goes upwards (because work is done agasinst gravity) and gravitational potential energy increase [latex] \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{2} m V_{2}^{2}=m g h^{\prime} [/latex] [latex] h^{\prime}=\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2 g}=0.64 \mathrm{m}[/latex]

question:
Question 41 A pinion with radius [latex]r_{1}[/latex] , and inertia [latex]I_{1}[/latex]  is driving a gear with radius [latex]r_{2}[/latex]  and inertia [latex]I_{2}[/latex] . Torque 
[latex]\tau _{1}[/latex]  is applied on pinion. The following are free body diagrams of pinion and gear showing important forces (F1 and F2) of interaction. Which of the following relations hold true?
solution: [latex]\tau_{1}-F_{1} r_{1} =I_{1} \theta_{1}\qquad \ldots(i)[/latex] [latex] F_{1} =F_{2}\qquad\ldots(ii)[/latex] [Action and reaction are equal by Newton's 3rd law] [latex] F_{2} r_{2}=\tau_{2}=I_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2}\ldots(iii)[/latex] From (ii) and (iii) [latex] F_{2}=F_{1}=\frac{I_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2}}{r_{2}}\qquad\ldots(iv)[/latex] From (i) and (iv) [latex] \tau_{1}-\left(\frac{I_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2}}{r_{2}}\right) r_{1}=I_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1}\qquad\ldots(v)[/latex] We know, [latex] r_{1} \omega_{1}=r_{2} \omega_{2} [/latex] [latex] r_{1} \dot{\theta}_{1}=r_{2} \dot{\theta}_{2}[/latex] Differentiating with respect to time [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1} &=r_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2} \\ \ddot{\theta}_{2} &=\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} \ddot{\theta}_{1} \\ \tau_{1} &=I_{1} \ddot{\theta}_{1}+\frac{I_{2}}{r_{2}}\left[\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} \ddot{\theta}_{1}\right] r_{1} \\ \tau_{1} &=\left[I_{1}+I_{2}\left[\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}}\right]^{2}\right] \ddot{\theta}_{1} \\ \tau_{2} &=I_{2} \ddot{\theta}_{2}=F_{2} r_{2} \\ F_{2} &=\frac{I_{2}}{r_{2}} \ddot{\theta}_{2}=\frac{I_{2}}{r_{2}}\left[\frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}} \ddot{\theta}_{1}\right] \\ F_{2} &=I_{2} \frac{r_{1}}{r_{2}^{2}} \ddot{\theta}_{1} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 42 A mobile phone has a small motor with an eccentric mass used for vibrator mode. The location of the eccentric mass on motor with respect to center of gravity (CG) of the mobile and the rest of the dimensions of the mobile phone are shown. The mobile is kept on a flat horizontal surface. Given in addition that the eccentric mass = 2 grams, eccentricity = 2.19 mm, mass of the mobile = 90 grams, g = 9.81 [latex]m/s^{2}[/latex] . Uniform speed of the motor in RPM for which the mobile will get just lifted off the ground at the end Q is approximately
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \Sigma M_{P} &=0 \text { [moment about } P=0] \\ m g \times 6 &=m_{0}\left(2.19 \times 10^{-3}\right)\left(\omega^{2}\right) \times[9] \\ 90 \times 9.81 \times 6 &=2\left(2.19 \times 10^{-3}\right) \omega^{2} \times 9 \\ 366.5836 &=\omega=\frac{2 \pi \mathrm{N}}{60} \\ \text { or } \quad N &=3500.6158 \mathrm{rpm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 43 A machine element is subjected to the following bi-axial state of stress:  [latex]\sigma _{x}[/latex] = 80 MPa;  [latex]\sigma _{y}[/latex] = 20 MPa; [latex]\tau _{xy}[/latex]  = 40 MPa. If the shear strength of the material is 100 MPa, the factor of safety as per Tresca's maximum shear stress theory is
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{c} \sigma_{1,2}=\frac{1}{2}\left[\left(\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}\right) \pm \sqrt{\left(\sigma_{x}+\sigma_{y}\right)^{2}+4 \tau_{x y}^{2}}\right] \\ =\frac{1}{2}[(80+20) \pm \sqrt{(60)^{2}+4 \times 40^{2}}] \\ \sigma_{1}=100 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \sigma_{2}=0 \mathrm{MPa} \\ \left(\tau_{\max }\right)=\frac{\sigma_{1}}{2}=50 \mathrm{MPa} \\ F(\text { Factor of safety })=\frac{\tau_{y s}}{\tau_{\max }}=\frac{100}{50}=2 \end{array}[/latex]

question: Question 44 A cantilever beam with flexural rigidity of 200 N.[latex]m^{2}[/latex]  is loaded as shown in the figure. The deflection (in mm) at the tip of the beam is  _______
solution: [latex]EI=200\mathrm{Nm}^{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} y_{c} &=y_{B}+\theta_{B}(1-a) \\ y_{B} &=\frac{P a^{3}}{3 E I} \\ &=\frac{500 \times\left\{\frac{50}{1000}\right\}^{3}}{3 \times 200} \\ &=1.04167 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m} \\ \theta_{B} &=\frac{P a^{2}}{2 E I} \\ &=\frac{500 \times\left\{\frac{50}{1000}\right\}^{2}}{2 \times 200} \\ &=3.125 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{rad} \\ y_{c}=& y_{B}+\theta_{B}(L-a) \\ &=\left[1.04167 \times 10^{-4}\right] \\ &\qquad+\left[3.125 \times 10^{-3} \times \frac{50}{1000}\right] \\ &=2.60417 \times 10^{-4} \mathrm{m} \\ &=0.26042 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 A precision instrument package (m = 1 kg) needs to be mounted on a surface vibrating at 60 Hz. It is desired that only 5% of the base surface vibration amplitude be transmitted to the instrument. Assume that the isolation is designed with its natural frequency significantly lesser than 60 Hz, so that the effect of damping may be ignored. The stiffness (in N/m) of the required mounting pad is _____
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \text { Given, } \omega&=2 \pi f=2 \pi \times 60 \\ \omega &=120 \pi \\ m &=1 \mathrm{kg} \\ \frac{F_{\mathrm{TR}}}{F_{0}} &=\frac{\sqrt{1+(2 \xi r)^{2}}}{\sqrt{\left(1-r^{2}\right)^{2}+(2 \xi r)^{2}}} \end{aligned}[/latex] No damping, [latex] \begin{aligned} \therefore \quad \xi &=0 \\ \frac{F_{\mathrm{TR}}}{F_{0}} &=0.05 \\ 0.05 &=\frac{1}{r^{2}-1} \\ r^{2}-1 &=20 \\ r &=\sqrt{21} \\ \frac{\omega}{\omega_{n}} &=\sqrt{21} \\ \frac{120 \pi}{\omega_{n}} &=\sqrt{21} \\ \omega_{n} &=82.266 \\ \sqrt{\frac{K}{m}} &=82.266 \\ \sqrt{\frac{K}{1}} &=6767.728 \\ K &=6767.72 \mathrm{N} / \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 46 A horizontal plate has been joined to a vertical post using four rivets arranged as shown in the figure. The magnitude of the load on the worst loaded rivet (in N) is _______
solution: Primary force [latex]\left(P_{1}\right)=100 \mathrm{N} [/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{1}^{\prime \prime}&=P_{2}^{\prime \prime}=P_{3}^{\prime \prime}=P_{4}^{\prime \prime}=\frac{P_{e} \times r}{4 r^{2}} \\ &= \frac{400 \times 500 \times(40 \sqrt{2} / 2)}{4 \times\left(\frac{40 \sqrt{2}}{2}\right)^{2}} \\ P_{1}^{\prime \prime}&= \frac{400 \times 500 \times 20 \sqrt{2}}{4 \times(20 \sqrt{2})^{2}} \\&= \frac{400 \times 500}{4 \times 20 \sqrt{2}} \\ P_{1}^{\prime \prime}&= 1767.766 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned} [/latex] (1 and 4) are worst loaded [latex] \therefore P_{\text {net }}^{2}=P_{1}+P_{1}^{\prime \prime 2}+2 P_{1} P_{1}^{\prime \prime} \cos 45^{\circ} [/latex] [latex] P_{\text {net }}=1839.83 \mathrm{N}[/latex]

question: Question 47 For flow through a pipe of radius R, the velocity and temperature distribution are as follows  [latex]u(r,x)=C_{1} [/latex]  and [latex]T(r,x)=C_{2}[1-(\frac{r}{R})^{3}],[/latex] where [latex]C_{1}[/latex]   and [latex]C_{2}[/latex]   are constants.  The bulk mean temperature is given by [latex]T_{m}=\frac{2}{U_{m}R^{2}}\int_{0}^{R}u(r,x)T(r,x)rdr[/latex] , with [latex]U_{m}[/latex]  being the mean velocity of flow. The value of [latex]T_{m}[/latex] is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} u(r, x)&=C_{1} \\ T(r, x)&=C_{2}\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] \\ T_{m}&=\frac{2}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R} u(r, x) T(r, x) r d r \\ &=\frac{2}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R} C_{1} \times C_{2}\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] r d r \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R}\left[1-\left(\frac{r}{R}\right)^{3}\right] r d r \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}} \int_{0}^{R}\left(r-\frac{r^{4}}{R^{3}}\right) d r \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{r^{2}}{2}-\frac{r^{5}}{5 R^{3}}\right]_{0}^{R}\\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{R^{2}}{2}-\frac{R^{5}}{5 R^{3}}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{R^{2}}{2}-\frac{R^{2}}{5}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}}\left[\frac{5 R^{2}-2 R^{2}}{10}\right] \\ &=\frac{2 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m} R^{2}} \times \frac{3}{10} R^{2}=\frac{0.6 C_{1} C_{2}}{U_{m}} \quad\ldots(i) \end{aligned}[/latex] since [latex] u(r, x)=C_{1}[/latex], constant [latex]U_{m}=C_{1} [/latex] Substituting [latex]U_{m}=C_{1} [/latex] in above Eq. (i), we get [latex] T_{m}=\frac{0.6 C_{1} C_{2}}{C_{1}}=0.6 C_{2}[/latex]

question: Question 48 Match the following pairs:
solution: [latex]  \nabla \times \vec{V}=0 [/latex] Irrotional flow [latex]  \nabla \cdot \vec{V}=0 \quad [/latex] Incompressible continuity eq. [latex]  \frac{D \vec{V}}{D t}=0 [/latex] Zero acceleration of fluid particle [latex] \frac{\partial \vec{V}}{d t}=0 \quad [/latex] Steady flow

question: Question 49 The velocity field of an incompressible flow is given by [latex]V=(a_{1}x+a_{2}y+a_{3}z)i[/latex] + [latex] (b_{1}x+b_{2}y+b_{3}z)j[/latex] + [latex] (c_{1}x+c_{2}y+c_{3}z)k[/latex] , where [latex]a_{1}= 2[/latex]  and [latex]c_{3}= -4[/latex]. The value of [latex]b_{2}[/latex] is ___________
solution: From continuity equation [latex] \begin{aligned} \frac{\partial u}{\partial x}+\frac{\partial v}{\partial y}+\frac{\partial w}{\partial z} &=0 \\ a_{1}+b_{2}+c_{2} &=0 \\ 2+b_{2}-4 &=0\\ \text{or}\quad b_{2}=4-2&=2 \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 50 A 10 mm diameter electrical conductor is covered by an insulation of 2 mm thickness. The conductivity of the insulation is 0.08 W/m-K and the convection coefficient at the insulation surface is 10 W/[latex]m^{2}[/latex]-K. Addition of further insulation of the same material will
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} d_{i} &=10 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \qquad r_{i} &=\frac{d}{2}=\frac{10}{2}=5 \mathrm{mm} \\ t &=2 \mathrm{mm} \\ \therefore \qquad r_{0} &=r_{i}+t \\ &=5+2=7 \mathrm{mm}\\ k &=0.08 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{mK} \\ h_{0} &=10 \mathrm{W} / \mathrm{m}^{2} \mathrm{K} \end{aligned} [/latex] Critical radius, [latex] \begin{aligned} r_{c} &=\frac{k}{h_{0}}=\frac{0.08}{10} \\ &=0.008 \mathrm{m}=8 \mathrm{mm} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] A s_{0}, r_{0}, [/latex] the heat loss increase to a maximum and then then decrease heat loss by addition of insulation.

options.C: increase heat loss to a maximum and then decrease heat loss
options.D: decrease heat loss to a minimum and then increase heat loss

question: Question 51 Temperature of nitrogen in a vessel of volume 2 [latex]m^{3}[/latex]  is 288 K. A U-tube manometer connected to the vessel shows a reading of 70 cm of mercury (level higher in the end open to atmosphere). The universal gas constant is 8314 J/kmol-K, atmospheric pressure is 1.01325 bar, acceleration due to gravity is 9.81 m/[latex]s^{2}[/latex]  and density of mercury is 13600 kg/[latex]m^{3}[/latex] . The mass of nitrogen (in kg) in the vessel is _____________
solution: [latex]\begin{array}{l} \left(P_{\text {absolute }}\right) \text { of } N_{2}=[101.3 \mathrm{kPa}+w h] \mathrm{kPa} \\ =101.3+\left(13.6 \times 9.81 \times \frac{70}{100}\right) \mathrm{kPa} \\ =194.6 \mathrm{kPa} \end{array}[/latex] As [latex]N_{2}[/latex] being ideal gas, [latex] \begin{aligned} p V &=m R T \\ m &=\left(\frac{p V}{R T}\right) \mathrm{kg} \\ \text{where}\quad R &=\frac{8.314}{28}=0.296 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K}\\ \therefore \qquad m&=\frac{194.6 \times 2}{0.296 \times 288}\\ &=4.56 \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 52 Air ([latex]\rho =1.2 kg/m^{3}[/latex] and kinematic viscosity, [latex]v=2\times 10^{-5}m^{2}/s[/latex] ) with a velocity of 2 m/s flows over the top surface of a flat plate of length 2.5 m.  If the average value of friction coefficient is [latex]C_{f}=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{R_{e_{x}}}}[/latex],  the total drag force (in N) per unit width of the plate is _______
solution: Drag force = average shear stress x area where [latex]\bar{\tau}=[/latex] average shear stress [latex] =\bar{C}_{f} \times \frac{\rho U_{\infty}^{2}}{2} [/latex] [latex] =\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{\mathrm{Re}_{L}}} \times \frac{\rho U_{0}^{2}}{2} [/latex] [latex] Re_{L}= [/latex]Local Reynold's number at trailing edge, [latex] =\frac{U_{\infty} L}{\mu}[/latex] [latex] =\frac{2 \times 2.5 \times 1.2}{1.2 \times 2 \times 10^{-5}} [/latex] [latex] =2.5 \times 10^{5}(\text { laminar flow })[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} \text { Drag force: } F_{D} &=\bar{\tau} \times A \\ &=\frac{1.328}{\sqrt{2.5 \times 10^{5}}} \times \frac{1.2 \times 2^{2}}{2} \times(2.5 \times 1) \\ &=0.0159 \mathrm{N} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 53 Water ([latex]\rho =1000 kg/m^{3}[/latex]) flows through a venturimeter with inlet diameter 80 mm and throat diameter 40 mm. The inlet and throat gauge pressures are measured to be 400 kPa and 130 kPa respectively. Assuming the venturimeter to be horizontal and neglecting friction, the inlet velocity (in m/s)  is _______
solution: Given data: [latex] \begin{aligned} \rho &=1000 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{m}^{3} \\ d_{1} &=80 \mathrm{mm}=0.08 \mathrm{mm} \\ d_{2} &=40 \mathrm{mm}=0.04 \mathrm{m} \end{aligned}[/latex] [latex] \begin{aligned} p_{1}&=400 \mathrm{kPa}=400 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \\ p_{2}&=130 \mathrm{kPa}=130 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{Pa} \end{aligned} [/latex] Applying Bernoullis equation between sections 1 and 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}&+z_{1}=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g}+z_{2} \\ \text{where }z_{1}&=z_{1} \text{ for horizontal pipe}\\ \therefore \quad \frac{p_{1}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{1}^{2}}{2 g}&=\frac{p_{2}}{\rho g}+\frac{V_{2}^{2}}{2 g} \\ or \quad \frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{\rho g}&=\frac{V_{2}^{2}-V_{1}^{2}}{2 g} \\ or \quad \frac{p_{1}-p_{2}}{\rho}&=\frac{V_{2}^{2}-V_{2}^{2}}{2} \quad\ldots(i)\\ \end{aligned}[/latex] Applying continuity equation between sections and 2 [latex]\begin{aligned} A_{1} V_{1}&=A_{2} V_{2} \\ \frac{\pi}{4} d_{1}^{2} V_{1}&=\frac{\pi}{2} d_{2}^{2} V_{2}\\ \text{or }\quad d_{1}^{2} V_{1}&=d_{2}^{2} V_{2}\\ \text{or }\quad V_{2}&=\left(\frac{d_{1}}{d_{2}}\right)^{2} V_{1}=\left(\frac{0.08}{0.04}\right)^{2} V_{1} \\ V_{2}&=4 V_{1}\\ \text{Substituting } V_{2}&=4 V_{1} \text{ in Eq. }( i ),\text{ we get}\\ \frac{400 \times 10^{3}-130 \times 10^{3}}{1000}&=\frac{\left(4 V_{1}\right)^{2}-V_{1}^{2}}{2} \\ 540&=16 \mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}-V_{1}^{2} \\ 540&=15 \mathrm{V}_{1}^{2}\\ or \quad V_{1}^{2}&=36\\ or \quad V_{1}&=6 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\\ \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 54 A well insulated rigid container of volume 1[latex]m^{3}[/latex]  contains 1.0 kg of an ideal gas [[latex]C_{p}[/latex] = 1000 J/(kg.K) and [latex]C_{v}[/latex] = 800 J/(kg.K)] at a pressure of [latex]10^{5}[/latex] Pa. A stirrer is rotated at constant rpm in the container for 1000 rotations and the applied torque is 100 N-m.  The final temperature of the gas (in K) is
solution: Work done = Torque [latex]\times[/latex] angular displacement [latex] \begin{aligned} &=100 \times 2 \pi \times 1000=-628.318 \mathrm{kJ} \\ p_{1} V_{1} &=m R T_{1} \\ T_{1}=\frac{p_{1} V_{1}}{m R} &=\frac{10^{2} \times 1}{0.2 \times 1}=500 \mathrm{K} \\ \therefore \quad R &=c_{p}-c_{v}=0.2 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \end{aligned}[/latex] According to 1 st law of thermodynamic [latex] \begin{array}{l} \quad Q-W=\Delta U \\ -(-628.318) \mathrm{kJ}=m c_{v}\left(T_{2}-T_{1}\right) \\ \text { or } \quad T_{2}=500+\frac{628.318}{1 \times 0.8}=1285.39 \mathrm{K} \end{array}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 Steam enters a well insulated turbine and expands isentropically throughout. At an intermediate pressure, 20 percent of the mass is extracted for process heating and the remaining steam expands isentropically to 9 kPa. Inlet to turbine: P = 14 MPa, T =[latex]560^{\circ}C[/latex] , h = 3486 kJ/kg, s = 6.6 kJ/(kg.K) Intermediate stage: h = 2776 kJ/kg Exit of turbine: P = 9 kPa,  [latex]h_{f}[/latex] = 174 kJ/kg,  [latex]h_{g}[/latex] = 2574 kJ/kg,  [latex]s_{f}[/latex] = 0.6 kJ/(kg.K), [latex]s_{g}[/latex] = 8.1 kJ/(kg.K) If the flow rate of steam entering the turbine is 100 kg/s, then the work output (in MW) 
 is _________
solution: Given data: At turbine inlet: [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{1} &=3486 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ \mathrm{s}_{1} &=6.6 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \mathrm{K} \\ m_{1} &=100 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] At intermediate stage: [latex] \begin{aligned} h_{2}&=2776 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ m_{2}&=0.2 \mathrm{m}_{1}=0.2 \times 100=20 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}[/latex] At turbine exit: [latex] \begin{aligned} P_{3} &=9 \mathrm{kPa} \\ m_{3} &=0.8 \mathrm{m}_{1}=0.8 \times 100=80 \mathrm{kg} / \mathrm{s}\\ \mathrm{At} \quad P_{3}&=9 \mathrm{kPa} \\ h_{f} &=174 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ h_{g} &=2574 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \\ s_{f} &=0.6 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ s_{g} &=8.1 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kgK} \\ s_{3} &=s_{1}=s_{f}+x_{3}\left(s_{g}-s_{f}\right) \\ 6.6 &=0.6+x_{3}(8.1-0.6) \\ 6 &=7.5 x_{3} \\ \text{or}\quad x_{3} &=0.8\\ h_{3}&=h_{f}+x_{3}\left(h_{g}-h_{f}\right)\\ &=174+0.8(2574-174) \\ &=2094 \mathrm{kJ} / \mathrm{kg} \end{aligned}[/latex] Work output, [latex] \begin{aligned} W &=m_{1}\left(h_{1}-h_{2}\right)+m_{3}\left(h_{2}-h_{3}\right) \\ &=100(3486-2776) \\ &\quad +80(2776-2094) \\ &=71000+54560 \\ &=125560 \mathrm{kW} \\ &=125.56 \mathrm{MW} \end{aligned}[/latex]

Question 65 Lamenting the gradual sidelining of the arts in school curricula, a group of prominent artists wrote to the chief minister last year, asking him to allocate more funds to support art education in schools. However, no such increase has been announced in this year's budget. The artists expressed their deep anguish at their request not being approved, but many of them approved, but many of them remain optimistic about funding in the future. Which of the statements (s) below is/are logically valid and can be inferred from the above statements? i.  The artists expected funding for the arts to increase this year. ii.  
The chief minister was receptive to the idea of increasing funding for arts. iii.  The chief minister is a prominent artist. iv.  Schools are giving less importance to arts education these days
